data.title: Weekly - Steve G Tennis
data.text: International Weekly Official News of the ATP Tour Volume 10 Issue 11 April 10 , 2000 www.atptour.com Inside Player Services ..................5 ATP Champions Race ....6 Results ..............................10 Upcoming Events..........14 Calendar ..........................16 DAVIS CUP REVIEW Defending Champions Australia Lead Tough Foursome to Semifinals As always, the quarterfinals of the Davis Cup provided enough drama and excitement to have the Hollywood script writers looking for their notepads. But as John McEnroe’s U.S. team kept their supporters on tenterhooks against the Czech Republic under the famous Los Angeles landscape, defending champions Australia moved safely into the semifinals with a 3-2 win over Germany. Meanwhile, Brazil and Spain also booked their places in the last four with victories on home soil. Like all good dramas, the semifinals could not have been determined in more different circumstances. As John Newcombe enjoyed the luxury of an unassailable 3-0 in Adelaide, it was de ja vu for McEnroe, as his team fought back from 2-1 down to defeat the Czechs— just as they did against Zimbabwe in the previous round. And as Spain carried out a crushing 4-1 victory over Yevgeny Kafelnikov and his Russian counterparts in Malaga, Fernando Meligeni helped lead Brazil to a last-gasp 3-2 win over the Slovak Republic in Rio. With six of the current leaders in the ATP Champions Race 2000 all in Davis Cup action, and Mark Philippoussis on the physio bench, the big guns were all out for Davis Cup glory. But even with the might of Andre Agassi and Pete Sampras on the American team, the Czechs did everything they could to upset the form-books. After Jiri Novak played what he described as one of the best matches of his life to inflict a straight sets defeat on Sampras in the opening rubber, it was left to Agassi to settle the score against Slava Dosedel. But as Novak teamed up with David Rikl to record a shock win over Alex O’Brien and current doubles No. 1 Jared Palmer to give the Czechs a 2-1 lead, an upset looked on the cards until Agassi once again came to the rescue by handing Novak only his third Davis Cup Davis Cup Review, Page 2➔ ATP Tour Announces New Positions in Television, Internet and New Media The ATP Tour, governing body of the international men’s professional tennis circuit, announced several significant staff changes as part of its new direction for the 21st Century. The moves follow the Tour’s historic $1.2 billion, ten-year agreement, in effect since January 1, 2000, making ISL Worldwide the exclusive representatives of the Tour’s and its elite tournaments’ television and marketing rights. The personnel changes include the following: • Jon Wigley will be leaving his position as ATP Tour Vice President/Marketing & Television to head up the Tour’s Internet ventures with partners Kabel New Media and ISL through their joint venture company, Sports Interactive AG (SIAG). At SIAG, Wigley will be one of the managing directors overseeing development of the Tour’s offical websites, ATPTour.com and Masters-Series.com. • Murray Swartzberg, a former executive at modis who managed IT projects for numerous Fortune 1000 companies, has been hired as Vice President/Information Technology to head up the Tour’s activities in technology and new media. While working as managing director in modis’ Idea Integration division, Swartzberg recently completed an extensive review of the ATP Tour’s IT operations and helped the Tour launch an IntraNet site for the players at the Tennis Masters Series-Indian Wells tournament this past March. • Jonathan Marks, Director of TV Production, has been promoted to the new position of Vice President/Television. Marks will continue to manage the Tour’s television news service, a key promotional vehicle for men’s tennis, and work closely with ISL Tennis in the continued implementation of the Tour’s television and marketing contract. • Paul Macpherson, former Editor of Australian Tennis Magazine and News Editor of www.oncourt.com, the official website of Continued, Page 2➔ With Andre Agassi,Yevgeny Kafelnikov and Pete Sampras currently leading the ATP Champions Race 2000, the top three positions on the Leader Board now match the 1999 year-end rankings. See page 6 for all the latest standings. LEADER BOARD POS PREV PTS 1st Andre Agassi/USA (1st) 249 2nd Yevgeny Kafelnikov/RUS (2nd) 223 3rd Pete Sampras/USA (3rd) 218 4th Lleyton Hewitt/AUS (4th) 187 5th Magnus Norman/SWE (5th) 185 6th Nicolas Kiefer/GER (6th) 137 7th Thomas Enqvist/SWE (7th) 136 8th Gustavo Kuerten/BRA (8th) 134 9th Alex Corretja/ESP (9th) 131 10T Mark Philippoussis/AUS (10T) 130 10T Tim Henman/GBR (10T) 130 OTHER NOTABLES 12T Nicolas Lapentti/ECU (12T) 111 12T Younes El Aynaoui (12T) 111 Notes & Quotes Following crowd disturbances at the Davis Cup tie between Chile and Argentina in Santiago, referee Tony Hernandez suspended play with Chile leading the tie 1-0 and with Mariano Zabaleta (ARG) leading Nicolas Massu (CHI) in the second singles rubber. Hernandez asked for the tie to be played behind closed doors, but the Argentineans flew home saying their safety could not be guaranteed. Hernandez awarded the tie 5-0 to Chile. The Davis Cup Committee will be giving consideration to the tie at its meeting on Thursday, April 13, 2000. Notes & Quotes, Page 3➔
